author: Matt Mirande
title: grid
body: I wanted to see if I could replicate analog TV snow... I guess I miss it? Anyway, giant pixelated background .png. Each block is 12px square. My script simply assigns a random multiple of 12 to the background image's X & Y position. To keep the visual smooth, I make sure the new position isn't too close to the old one and that the image still covers all of the screen. MAGIC!

author: Matt Mirande
title: balls
body: During his talk @ JSConf 2010 (video), Dmitry Baranovskiy explained how you could export a vector graphic from Adobe Illustrator and use it with Raphael.js. (Me = :-O) So, I gave it a whirl. The "busticated" text / logo is an exported SVG path. The tricky bit with this one (at least for me) was cleaning up. After a certain number of circles are drawn, I start deleting the old ones.

author: Matt Mirande
title: hypno
body: Still playing around with Raphael.js. This time I recursively draw some circles then animate them in an attempt to replicate the art from an old Spacemen 3 album. I also took a stab at drawing my own icon (the home icon you see top left). I'm pretty psyched on the ol' Raphael.js - lots of possibilities!

author: Matt Mirande
title: ascii
body: What can I say? I'm a sucker for ascii art. I couldn't resist taking a shot at drawing something using JavaScript. Tricky bits here are: Making sure the ascii output fits in the screen (try resizing & refreshing), drawing and styling the "X" characters (and links), and giving the user a way to bail out if things get too slow. Which they often do. Especially in IE. Sorry! (li'l help?)

author: Matt Mirande
title: moballs
body: More fun with Raphael.js. A sort of variant on experiment #2. This time I use the whole screen and animate the circles as they are drawn and removed.

author: Matt Mirande
title: ping
body: I love finding random bits of history online. Ages ago I came across a vintage Submarine Sonar Operator's Manual and thought it might make a cool show poster. I got voted down but always had a soft spot for the image. When I was looking around for my next experiment, I thought "perfect! I'll just animate some bits and toss it up there". Yeah. Wrong. On the bright-side, a total lesson in feature-creep. Drag the sub around and click the destroyer to start the search. We got a little HTML5 audio action in there. Some ham-handed collision detection. Scaling (resize browser and refresh). And a bonus - See the Doppler effect in action! Dood. Fahkin' Science! SVG help via the magnificent Raphael.js, Audio samples by ERH & InfoBandit (courtesy of the FreeSound Project)
